DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC

FOMC raised rates by 25 bps to 1.50%-1.75% as expected and maintained its view for 3 hikes in 2018 but now sees 6 hikes through the end of 2019 (Prev. 5) and 8 hikes through 2020 (Prev. 7), while it also raised its longer-term rate projection slightly. The Fed stated that the outlook has strengthened, although also added that activity has been rising at a “moderate rate” which was a slight downgrade from the previous assessment where it has been judged solid. In the post meeting press conference, Fed Chair Powell struck a balanced tone revealing little by way of new information and reiterated the Fed data-dependent stance. Markets traded choppy in the wake of the press conference but ultimately the result was USD weakness, equities selling off, and treasuries paring back knee jerk loses in the wake of the rate decision.

ASIA-PAC

RBNZ kept the Official Cash Rate at 1.75% vs. Exp. 1.75% (Prev. 1.75%) and reiterated that monetary policy will remain accommodative for a considerable period, while it also noted that numerous uncertainties that remain and monetary policy may need to adjust accordingly. RBNZ further commented that economic growth is expected to strengthen and noted that inflation expectations remain well anchored at around 2%, but added that CPI is set to weaken in near term (Newswires)


UK/EU

EU’s Tusk confirmed UK transition period will be approved and that the EU will offer UK a Brexit transition deal on Friday, while there were earlier reports that EU leaders are to remind UK that nothing is agreed yet on Brexit and noted respect is needed with commitments to Ireland and Gibraltar (Newswires)

Catalan Parliament is expected to meet on Thursday and nominate Turull as its new President. (Newswires)

UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Jan) 4.3% vs. Exp. 4.4% (Prev. 4.4%). (Newswires)
UK Claimant Count Unem Change (Feb) 9.2k vs. Exp. -5.0k (Prev. -7.2k, Rev. -1.6k)
UK Average Week Earnings 3M YY (Jan) 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.5%)
UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Jan) 2.6% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.5%)

FX

After treading water ahead of the FOMC rate decision, the USD was subjected to 2-way action in the rate decision and during the press conference as traders digested a steeper rate trajectory in 2019/2020 with unchanged view for 3 hikes this year. Ultimately, the market chose to latch on to the dovish aspects of the decision/press conference with EUR/USD rising around a point to above 1.2300, while GBP/USD back above 1.4100 where it then found resistance around 1.4150.

Elsewhere, JPY resumed its course of strengthening – despite EURJPY catching a strong bid ahead of the Fed – with USDJPY briefly below the 106.00 handle, while commodity FX was stronger on the session helped by a bullish DoE inventory report as well as the USD weakness. In addition, CAD was also underpinned after US Trade Rep. Lighthizer confirmed NAFTA partners were converging on autos after the US dropped auto-content proposal in NAFTA discussions last week, which would have demanded vehicle imports to the US from Mexico and Canada should consist of 50% content from US.

Canadian PM Trudeau said a successful NAFTA deal is likely, while there were also comments from Canada’s Unifor union head that US NAFTA negotiators have dropped demand for 50% US content in vehicles produced in member nations. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks (16 Mar) -2.622M vs. Exp. 2.600M (Prev. 5.022M). (Newswires)
US crude production rose 26k to 10.407mln bpd.

DOE crude inventory figures showed a draw of 2.622mln – against expectations of a build – helping crude prices bounce higher. The narrative over the last couple of sessions has moved away from oversupply concerns, towards tensions in the middle east between Iran and Saudi Arabia, and curtailed Venezuelan output. Following on from this week’s reports that OPEC is looking to shift its targets towards average inventory levels, rather than the level of output cuts, the cartel today said that commercial oil stocks are now 44mln bbls above the 5-year average. And elsewhere, OPEC/non-OPEC technical committee sees compliance with oil output cuts in February at 138%, the highest level yet.

GEOPOLITICAL

Informal talks between North Korea, South Korea and the US have finished with delegates discussing the talks as "constructive" and taking place in a "positive atmosphere". (Newswires)


US

US President Trump plans to announce China tariffs on Thursday with the value of the tariffs likely around USD 50bln per year or slightly less, according to sources, while the White House later confirmed President Trump was to announce China tariffs on Thursday. (Newswires)

China is said to be planning countermeasures against US tariffs according to sources. Furthermore, the reports stated that
China could include levies targeting US agricultural exports from farmbelt states but also added that China is also weighing concessions, including easing restrictions on foreign investments in securities firms and insurance companies. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer that the US will take countermeasures if there is retaliation on agriculture products from China, while Lighthizer also commented that he hopes to complete tariffs exemptions by end of April and that the countries likely to be exempted from tariffs are NAFTA partners, South Korea, EU, Argentina and Brazil. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US equity indices were choppy after the FOMC’s rate decision and continued to trade erratically through the press conference. Ultimately, however, the net result was that the Emini, mini Dow and mini Nasdaq ended the press conference around the levels that it entered the rate decision, as traders struggle to digest the exact meaning from the FOMC. Equity traders seem to have settled on the narrative that conditions will remain accommodative, and the normalisation process will be gradual. Financials performed well as the FOMC rate path projection rose from 5 to 6 hikes through 2019 due to their sensitivity to interest rates. Away from the Fed, energy led gains after a bullish DOE report buoyed the sector. Consumer staples underperformed today being led by General Mills (GIS) following weak FY guidance in its earnings report, which also weighed on competitors like Kellogg’s (K), Conagra Brands (CAG) and JM Smucker (SJM); with the 4 companies closing the day as some of the largest underperformers. SPX -0.10% at 2714, DJI -0.07% at 24702 and NDX -0.42% at 6854.

Treasuries endured a rollercoaster ride through the FOMC today ultimately however there was little by way of new information and while 2s5s saw a knee jerk steepening the steepness pared back through the course of the press conference settling the day relatively unchanged at 61bp. 5s30s did see some knee jerk flattening but like other major curve spreads moves were pared back leave the 5s30s spread unchanged for the session at 159bp. 10year T-notes settled down 4+ ticks at 119-30+.

• SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, USD down, GBP up, JPY up, CAD up, Crude up, Treasuries up
  • REAR-VIEW: Fed Rate Decision
  • AHEAD: BoE Interest Rate decision; Trump China tariff announcements
     

* FOMC: Raised rates by 25 bps to 1.5%-1.75% as expected, Fed maintained its view for three hikes in 2018 but now sees 6 hikes through the end of 2019 (prev. five) and 8 hikes through 2020 (prev. seven); it also raised its longer-term rate projection slightly. On the US economy the Fed sounded optimistic, quoting that the outlook has strengthened though it said activity has been rising at a “moderate rate” (a slight downgrade from the previous assessment where it has been judged solid. In the post meeting press conference Powell struck a balanced tone revealing little by way of new information, reiterating the Fed data-dependent stance. Markets traded choppy in the wake of the press conference but ultimately the result was USD weakness, equities selling off, and treasuries paring back knee jerk loses in the wake of the rate decision.

* EQUITIES: US equity indices were choppy after the FOMC’s rate decision and continued to trade erratically through the press conference. Ultimately, however, the net result was that the Emini, mini Dow and mini Nasdaq ended the press conference around the levels that it entered the rate decision, as traders struggle to digest the exact meaning from the FOMC. Equity traders seem to have settled on the narrative that conditions will remain accommodative, and the normalisation process will be gradual. Financials performed well as the FOMC rate path projection rose from 5 to 6 hikes through 2019 due to their sensitivity to interest rates. Away from the Fed, energy led gains after a bullish DOE report buoyed the sector. Consumer staples underperformed today being led by General Mills (GIS) following weak FY guidance in its earnings report, which also weighed on competitors like Kellogg’s (K), Conagra Brands (CAG) and JM Smucker (SJM); with the 4 companies closing the day as some of the largest underperformers.

* TREASURIES: Treasuries endured a rollercoaster ride through the FOMC today ultimately however there was little by way of new information and while 2s5s saw a knee jerk steepening the steepness pared back through the course of the press conference settling the day relatively unchanged at 61bp. 5s30s did see some knee jerk flattening but like other major curve spreads moves were pared back leave the 5s30s spread unchanged for the session at 159bp. 10 YEAR T-NOTE SETTLED DOWN 4+ TICKS AT 119-30+.

* FOREX: After treading water ahead of the FOMC rate decision USD was subjected to 2-way action after the rate decision and during the press conference as trader digested on one hand a steeper rate trajectory in 2019/2020 though remained unchanged for 2018, ultimately, the market chose to latch on to the dovish aspects of the decision/press conference with USDEUR rising to 1.2340. GBP was a beneficiary of USD weakness rising back above 1.41 where it has found resistance around 1.4150 the JPY resumes its course of strengthening – despite EURJPY catching a strong bid ahead of the Fed – USDJPY fell below the 106 handle heading into ASIAPAC. Commodity FX was stronger on the session helped by a bullish DoE inventory report as well as the USD weakness. EMFX also found strength against the USD and continued strengthening after the decision. CAD also continued the strength seen overnight after Lighthizer confirmed NAFTA partners were converging on autos after the US dropped auto-content proposal in NAFTA discussions last week, which would have demanded vehicle imports to the US from Mexico and Canada should consist of 50% content from US

* CRUDE: WTI (May) crude futures settle up USD 1.63 at USD 65.17; Brent (May) crude May futures settle up $2.05 at $69.47.

Following on from this week’s reports that OPEC is looking to shift its targets towards average inventory levels, rather than the level of output cuts, the cartel today said that commercial oil stocks are now 44mln bbls above the 5-year average. Daily FX Wrap: Firmer than forecast data props up Usd, and now its over to the Fed
content: The Loonie leap-frogged Sterling amidst more bullish NAFTA noises to reclaim top G10 spot in the run up to the FOMC, and Usd/Cad continued its retracement from year to date highs as a result. The psychological 1.3000 level took some effort to breach, as layers of bids/support at 1.2980 and 1.2960, but the pair is now testing the 1.2950 area. There was a brief bounce on a bigger than expected rebound in US exiting home sales, but the next independent driver for the Greenback will come from the Fed via the SEP, dot plots and tone of new Fed chair Powell’s first post-meeting presser. Meanwhile, Cable got close to weekly highs just ahead of 1.4100 with the aid of stronger UK wage data and some jobs components, which could prompt some of the more hawkish BoE voters to declare intentions if not their hand on Thursday. The Chf and Eur are vying for 3rd place among majors, with the former up to 0.9520 vs the Usd and close to 1.1700 vs the single currency amidst talk of a large Franc buy order. Eur/Usd hugged the top of a 1.2240-95 range and near extremely large option expiries (1.4 bn at the 1.2280 strike for example), and Usd/Jpy also drifted back towards big expiries (3 bn+ at 106.00) from a peak around 106.50, but with a fair degree of safe-haven positioning after reports that China is preparing to retaliate against US plans to impose import tariffs. However, the Aud held around 0.7700 vs its US counterpart with promise of exemptions from the US steel and aluminium taxes in contrast to its Nzd antipodean peer that saw more selling/underperformance and a decline through 0.7180 chart support to test 0.7150 at one stage on the likelihood that the RBNZ will not be anywhere near as hawkish as the FOMC might or is seen to be. Note, options see a 70 pip break even on the 2 Central Bank events.

subject: Daily US Equity Opening News: Earnings from General Mills (GIS) and FedEx (FDX)
content:
20th March 2018

EARNINGS

  • General Mills (GIS) – Q3 Adj. EPS USD 0.79 vs Exp. USD 0.78, revenue USD 3.88bln vs Exp. USD 3.78bln. It also cut its FY18 constant currency adj. EPS forecast to between flat and up 1%, compared to previous guidance of 3 to 4% increase. (Newswires)
  • Laureate Education (LAUR) – Q4 EPS USD 0.48 vs Exp. USD 0.29, revenue USD 1.26bln vs Exp. USD 1.23bln. (Newswires)
  • FedEx (Q3) - Adj. EPS USD 3.72 vs Exp. USD 3.16, revenue USD 16.5bln vs Exp. USD 16.18bln. Notes benefits of tax reform will be offset by tariffs. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – An executive at the tech giant, Jimmy Iovine will transition into a consulting role in August and will step back from its Apple Music. Separately, the co. lost it formerly dominant position in the education marketplace to Alphabet’s (GOOG) Google unit and to Microsoft (MSFT). (CNBC / WAPO)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The pharmaceutical giant’s CFO and executive vice president Dominic Caruso is to retire after 19 years with the company, Joseph Wolk will be his successor. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – The co. has signed a service agreement for a combined cycle power plant in Malaysia. Separately, its Transportation unit has secured 225 orders in 2018 for modernisations and has already completed the first 100 of Norfolk Southern’s (NSC) modernisations. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Agricultural Names (ADM, BG, MON, FMC) – WSJ report China is to hit back with countermeasures on Tariffs by implementing tariffs on agricultural exports. (Newswires)
  • Airlines (AAL, DAL) – American Airlines has cancelled 560 flights in the US due to the snowstorm and Delta are to cancel about 500 flights. (Newswires)
  • AutoZone (AZO) – The co. announced a new USD 1bln share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • Car Names (F, FCAU, TM) – Senators are raising concerns regarding explosive Takata Airbags and are pressing executives and regulators. Also, the US has dropped auto-content proposal in NAFTA discussions which could have demanded vehicle imports to the US from Mexico and Canada to consist of 50% contents from the US. (Newswires)
  • CSRA (CSRA) – The co. has declared a USD 0.10 quarterly cash dividend. (Newswires)
  • Deere (DE) – CEO of the company noted that it would be financially impacted by the US steel tariffs. (Newswires)
  • FedEx (FDX) – The co. is to now screen every package at two of its Texas facilities following recent explosions. Worth noting, an Austin bomb suspect has died in police confrontation. (Newswires)
  • Health Insurers (MET, AFL, CI, HUM) – WSJ reporting health insurers have adjusted to the effects of 2010 Affordable Care Act, may undercut lawmakers push to obtain funds to blunt possible premium raises. (Newswires)
  • Monsanto (MON) – The EU has cleared Bayer’s acquisition of the co., but it is subject to conditions, and the deal is still under review by US officials. (Newswires)
  • Nordstrom (JWN) – The retailer is no longer in talks with the Nordstrom family about potentially going private. (Newswires)
  • Salesforce (CRM) – UBS have said the co. should be bought following weakness from purchasing MuleSoft (MULE). (Newswires)

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: Equities remain cautious ahead of the FOMC rate decision and Feds Powell Press Conference
content:
21st March 2018

  • Equites remain cautious ahead of the FOMC rate decision and Fed’s Powell Press Conference
  • Sterling is stronger after strong UK earnings
  • Looking ahead, highlights include FOMC and RBNZ rate decisions, Fed’s Powell Conference

ASIA

Asian stocks took impetus from Wall St. where the major indices rebounded from the recent tech sell-off. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was marginally positive as Australia’s energy sector tracked the outperformance seen in its US counterparts, although gains were contained approaching today’s FOMC and with Japan closed for Vernal Equinox national holiday.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3396 (Prev. 6.3246). (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he has had very direct talks with China and that dialogue will continue, while he added that the general G20 view is to see China open its markets. (Newswires)

China Vice Commerce Minister said the nation will actively take steps to safeguard interests of its domestic industries following US trade investigations. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB's Smets says interest rates at current levels have been and are still absolutely necessary to avoid that inflation settles at too low levels. (NBB)

EU/UK/US

UK Trade Secretary Fox says FTA is not the UK's only approach to relationships, will also look at incremental steps to improve trade. (Newswires)

Italy's Forza Italia leader Silvio Berlusconi open to government pact with Five Star Movement. (La Repubblica)

US dropped auto-content proposal in NAFTA discussions last week, which would have demanded vehicle imports to the US from Mexico and Canada should consist of 50% content from US. (The Globe and Mail)

US President Trump stated they have started on phase 2 of tax reductions. (Newswires)

UK Average Week Earnings 3M YY (Jan) 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.5%)

UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Jan) 2.6% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.5%)

UK Claimant Count Unemployment Change (Feb) 9.2k vs. Exp. -5.0k (Prev. -7.2k, Rev. -1.6k)

UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Jan) 4.3% vs. Exp. 4.4% (Prev. 4.4%)

EQUITIES

European equities opened with a lack of firm direction, before edging lower (Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%) ahead of the FOMC meeting. The utilities sector is boosted following upgrades of Italy’s A2A (+2.3%) and Germany’s E.ON (+1.9%) by Kepler Chevreux. The FTSE 100 is weighed on by a firmer sterling. Simultaneously, UK retailers are taking a hit amid signs of consumer spending downturn; Moss Bros (-19.8%) crashing after the issue of a profit warning. Carpetright (-0.3%) has taken a loan from a significant shareholder to cover short-term capital requirements, Kingfisher (-6.8%) amongst the laggards following the Co. reporting a fall in earnings and expressing concerns on the outlook for the retail sector, warning that the UK market is tough. On the flip side, LSE (+0.9%) is at the top of the FTSE 100 amid talks that the 21-month Brexit transition deal agreed this week could prompt Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) of the US to make another bid approach.

FX

The Pound has jumped to the top of the G10 pile on above consensus (and CPI) UK earnings, the lowest unemployment rate since 1975 and a much bigger than expected rise in employment. In truth, the Gbp was already firmer back above 1.4000 vs a broadly softer Usd, but Cable climbed further towards Monday’s post-Brexit transition deal peak of 1.4088 to around 1.4075. Eur/Gbp retreated to the lower end of its 0.8760-25 range and 0.8700 support despite Eur/Usd rebounding from circa 1.2240 lows to just shy of 1.2300 before fading against the backdrop of mega expiry option interest between 1.2250-80 (total of 3.7 bn). The Greenback has handed back a chunk of yesterday’s net gains, and market contacts note a big drop in Usd/Chf that seemed order-based as the pair fell from highs near 0.9565 to 0.9520 or thereabouts, with Eur/Chf down around 1.1700 from 1.1750+ recent highs. However, the DXY is back near 90.000 from 90.400 at best with Usd/Cad retreating further from 1.3100+ to just above 1.3000 on reports that the US has softened its stance on autos in latest NAFTA talks, which also boosted the Peso (Usd/Mxn sub-18.6000 at one stage). Usd/Jpy trapped in tight 106.55-25 parameters and trade impacted by a Japanese holiday on top of typical pre-Fed caution, but the Kiwi continuing to underperform and in danger of triggering stops said to be situated at 0.7170 and 0.7150 ahead of the RBNZ that is expected to remain neutral if not dovish compared to the FOMC.

FIXED INCOME

No surprise to see renewed selling across the UK rates space on the back of forecast beating wages and other elements of the latest jobs data showing further strength, with Gilts now down through 121.00 at 120.84 (-51 ticks) and Short Sterling futures as much as 8 ticks adrift. Certainly, fuel for the BoE hawks ahead of Thursday’s rate verdict and of course another uptick in May hike probability. Bunds also creeping lower again, but incrementally, to 157.82 (-24 ticks) so far. 

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI (+0.4%), and Brent Crude (+0.5%) are extending gains fuelled by Middle East tensions, and a fall in Venezuelan oil output, the 6th largest OPEC oil producer. Yesterday’s API weekly inventories printed a surprise draw, providing additional support to the bullish oil movements. Looking at metals, gold (+0.3%) has edged higher having held above the key 1300 level. Base metals are somewhat mixed, copper (-0.3%) dipped lower following the global world refined copper market showing a 17k tonnes surplus in December against a deficit of 41K tonnes in November. China’s iron ore futures (+0.9%) have been buoyed by expectations of an increase in restocking demand saw a rebound after three consecutive declining sessions.

US API weekly crude stocks (16 Mar) -2.739M vs. Exp. 3.200M (Prev. 1.156M). (Newswires)

OPEC are said to be discussing a change of measures for success for the OPEC cut deal and that the Vienna meeting looked at a change to its inventory target. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Kremlin says Putin and Trump agreed to entrust preparations for their meeting to top diplomats; no date yet for meeting but preparation should begin as soon as possible. (Newswires)

Informal talks between North Korea, South Korea and the US have finished with delegates discussing the talks as "constructive" and taking place in a "positive atmosphere". (Newswires)

South Korean President Moon suggested that a 3-way summit between US, South Korea and North Korea is possible, while there were separate reports that South Korea offered to hold a high-level meeting with North Korea on March 29th. (Newswires)

subject: Bunds: probing further below recent 158.00 pivot
content: The 10 year German debt future has extended losses after marginally higher rebound from early Eurex lows to briefly trade flat at 158.06, and the heavier selling seems partly in sympathy with Gilts, but also technical as Tuesday’s intraday low was breached, albeit by just a few ticks at 157.85 vs 157.91. Nevertheless, Bunds have inched closer to nearest chart support at 157.80 and Monday’s session base at 157.67, while building in more in the way of accommodation for the upcoming auction.

ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION
BMW (BMW GY) expects 2018 pre-tax profit of over EUR 10bln
Short Sterling strip hit hard, Gilts also under pressure after mixed start
content: A tentative tone in UK debt and STIR futures off the Liffe opens has turned increasingly bearish in the run up to the Fed later today and BoE on Thursday, with Gilts initially straddling yesterday’s 121.39 Liffe close, but now succumbing to more pronounced downside pressure and hitting a 121.12 low (-27 ticks vs +4 ticks at one stage. Similarly, 3 month contracts were containing losses to just a tick for a while, but have been as much as 5 ticks underwater more recently. It remains highly uncertain whether the FOMC ratchets up rate guidance beyond the 3 hikes currently pencilled in for this year, but the BoE may be emboldened enough by Brexit developments to signal more policy normalisation and underpin market expectations for a ¼ point rise in May. Yesterday’s softer than expected inflation data could keep MPC hawks at bay, but any sign of wages picking up pace today may offset and on that note the latest IHS Markit survey suggests that household incomes are at post-GFC highs. Labour/earnings aside, public sector finances are also on show, but perhaps the biggest market-mover on the domestic front looms from Brussels and EU member states that are due air reservations about the preliminary transition ‘deal’ (news may be forthcoming on this front from midday).

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: Germany are to sell EUR 3bln 0.5% 2028 Bund
content:
Germany are to sell EUR 3bln 0.5% 2028 Bund

IFR:

- No outright concession, little curve concession as EGBs have rallied and bull flattened

- Better concession against OATs, BTPs

- Schatz redemption last Friday should provide underlying support

- Poor recent history for 10-year Bund auctions, 4 of last 5 have been technical failures

ING:

Today Germany will tap the DBR0.5 2/28 for €3bn. Some jitters in overall risk sentiment as well as the more dovish ECB has helped push the 10yr yield below 0.6% again and the Bund ASW wider towards 45bp. While outright valuations thus appear on the rich side, when viewed on the curve in a 5/10/30yr fly the 10yr sector remains on the cheaper end of valuations. In the broader EGB context, semi-core spreads versus Bunds continue to reside at very tight levels.

Barclays:

In outright terms, 10yr yields have rallied nearly 20bps since hitting highs in early Feb; however they still remain over 30bps above their December lows. In RV terms, the bond has cheapened around 1bps in the past month in ASW terms vs. DBR Aug 28th, although cheapening has come from a previous small benchmark premium and the bond still trades rich versus recent rolls. Cross market, since the end of March, 10yr Germany has cheapened around 4bps vs. France, 2.5bps vs. Holland and 3bps vs. Austria.

In terms of historical data:

Prev. b/c 1.2, average yield 0.67% and retention 19.6%

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are published shortly after.

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the

overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio

rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires

since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks took impetus from Wall St. where the major indices rebounded from the recent tech sell-off. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and KOSPI (+0.1%) were marginally positive as Australia’s energy sector tracked the outperformance seen in its US counterparts, although gains were contained approaching today’s FOMC and with Japan closed for Vernal Equinox national holiday. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) led the region as focus turned to earnings with the top performers in Hong Kong spurred by recent financial results.

FTSE 100

LSE (LSE LN) – Co. shares were seen higher yesterday amid talk among some dealers that the 21-month Brexit transition deal agreed this week could prompt Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) of the US to make another bid approach after being spurned during the exchange’s aborted merger talks with Germany’s Deutsche Börse (DB1 GY). (Times)

Daimler (DAI GY) – Chinese carmaker Geely (0175 HK) who recently acquired a 9.7% (USD 9bln) stake in Daimler, reported 2017 net profit that had more than doubled. Net profit rose 108% YY to USD 1.7bln vs Exp. USD 1.6bln on growing demand for its sports utility vehicles. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Ubisoft (UBI FP) – Vivendi (VIV FP) is to sell its entire stake in the Co., representing 27.3% of Ubisoft’s share capital for EUR 2bln, transaction realised at EUR 66/shr. Share buyback by Ubisoft of shares owned by Vivendi is accretive to all Ubisoft shareholders. Vivendi will not purchase any shares in Ubisoft for 5 years. As part of this transaction, Ubisoft and Tencent have announced a strategic partnership which will accelerate Ubisoft’s reach in China. Transaction was launched on the 20th March.  (Newswires)

subject: Italy's Forza Italia leader Silvio Berlusconi open to government pact with Five Star Movement according to La Repubblica
DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks took impetus from Wall St. where the major indices rebounded from the recent tech sell-off
content:
• Asian stocks took impetus from Wall St. where the major indices rebounded from the recent tech sell-off
  • CAD and MXN were the biggest overnight movers with the currencies lifted on news that the US dropped the contentious auto-content proposal in NAFTA discussions last week
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK jobs report, US existing home sales, DoEs, FOMC and RBNZ rate decisions, Fed Powell’s conference

ASIA

Asian stocks took impetus from Wall St. where the major indices rebounded from the recent tech sell-off. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and KOSPI (+0.1%) were marginally positive as Australia’s energy sector tracked the outperformance seen in its US counterparts, although gains were contained approaching today’s FOMC and with Japan closed for Vernal Equinox national holiday. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) led the region as focus turned to earnings with the top performers in Hong Kong spurred by recent financial results.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3396 (Prev. 6.3246)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he has had very direct talks with China and that dialogue will continue, while he added that the general G20 view is to see China open its markets. (Newswires)

China Vice Commerce Minister said the nation will actively take steps to safeguard interests of its domestic industries following US trade investigations. (Newswires)

UK/EU 

UK Trade Secretary Fox said that a FTA is not the UK's only approach to relationships and that the government will also look at incremental steps to improve trade. (Newswires)

Three of the nine members of the The Times’s BoE shadow monetary policy committee called for an immediate quarter-point increase. Two said they would raise rates in May and two others added that the Bank should lay the groundwork for rises this year. (Times)

FX

CAD and MXN were the biggest overnight movers with the currencies lifted on news that the US dropped the contentious auto-content proposal in NAFTA discussions last week. Elsewhere, the rest of currency markets were uneventful ahead of the upcoming Fed decision and dot-plot projections, in which EUR/USD faintly nursed losses and hovered near 1.2250 where there are large option expiries for today’s New York cut. Furthermore, GBP/USD just about held on the 1.4000 handle after the prior day’s losses which were triggered by the CPI miss, while USD/JPY was relatively unchanged amid the absence of market participants in Japan.

COMMODITIES

Crude prices held on to the gains from yesterday’s rally in which prices rose above USD 63/bbl and also briefly tested USD 64/bbl to the upside. The advances were attributed to ongoing Saudi-Iran tensions and further Venezuelan output declines, while the latest API inventory report was also supportive with headline crude stockpiles at a surprise drawdown. Elsewhere, gold found mild support as the USD pared back some of the strength heading into the FOMC decision later, while copper traded sideways and failed to benefit from the improvement in risk appetite.

US API weekly crude stocks (16 Mar) -2.739M vs. Exp. 3.200M (Prev. 1.156M). (Newswires)

OPEC are said to be discussing a change of measures for success for the OPEC cut deal and that the Vienna meeting looked at a change to its inventory target. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

South Korean President Moon suggested that a 3-way summit between US, South Korea and North Korea is possible, while there were separate reports that South Korea offered to hold a high-level meeting with North Korea on March 29th. (Newswires)
 

US

Treasury yields were higher by between 3-4bps across the curve in thinner trading conditions ahead of tomorrow's FOMC meeting, where a 25bps hike is priced with almost certainty. The main focus will be on the FOMC's rate path. Lifting rates may see a modest rally along the front of the curve, with risks that if inflation doesn’t materialise in the medium/longer-run, a curve inversion could be on the cards. A steeper curve will likely require the Fed to raise expectations of the terminal rate by notching up its long-term rate forecast, which could see underperformance in the five-year sector, BoAML says; the bank sees the 2s5s curve steepening, and the 5s30s flattening. US T-Note Futures (June) settled 9+ ticks lower at 120-03.

US dropped auto-content proposal in NAFTA discussions last week, which would have demanded vehicle imports to the US from Mexico and Canada should consist of 50% content from US. (The Globe and Mail)

US President Trump stated they have started on phase 2 of tax reductions. (Newswires)

US Senate Minority Leader Schumer said there are still a few sticking points on spending negotiations, but they are very close to coming up with legislation. (Newswires)
